author: sky.cactus
content:
From https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/692078615269212180/796592674052243476
> Users don't elongate the blockchain, miners do.
> If you read that research paper about the perils of fee-based incentives you will see that it is all based on the ability to decide which block to build on.
> 
> A coalition of the biggest miners can run clients that build on each other's blocks, thereby defining the longest chain.
> 
> How can a user change that with some unique cryptokitty attire?

Miners are a service provider.  If they are providing a service that no one desires then no one will value what they produce.  In this case, if miners produce blocks following a ruleset that no one cares about, then those blocks (and the ETH balances in them) will not be of value to anyone.

author: superluminal0
content:
So let's say you and 5 other guys decide to hardfork ETH to 2.0.

4 petahash of miners disagree with you.

What happens next?

author: sky.cactus
content: Me and 5 other guys will participate in one chain, the 4 petahashes of miners will participate in the other chain.  Every user can decide which of those two chains they want to participate in.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is a healthy chain split and there isn't anything wrong with it.  Freedom of choice and all that. ðŸ˜„

author: superluminal0
content:
Fair enough, and we are in agreement after all.

There is a small question about which of those chains gets to deposit ETH on the exchanges though...

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, many users delegate their decision making to exchanges, which I find unfortunate but is how the system works.
